Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE Track I: Distributed Sensing Collective to Capture 3D Soundscapes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Cyber-Physical Systems Program in the Division of Computer and Network Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, the Information and Intelligent Systems Program in the Division of Information and Intelligent Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, the Computer Systems Research Program in the Division of Computer and Network Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, and the Software and Hardware Foundations Program in the Division of Computing and Communications Foundations in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering.

Sound plays a vital role in the ocean ecosystem as many organisms rely on acoustics for navigation, communication, detecting predators, and finding food. Therefore, the 3D underwater soundscape, i.e., the combination of sounds present in the immersive underwater environment, is of extreme importance to understand and protect underwater ecosystems. This project is creating a transformative distributed ocean observing system for studying the underwater soundscape at revolutionary spatial (~100 meters) and temporal (~100 seconds) resolutions that is also able to simultaneously resolve small-scale ocean current flow. These breakthroughs are achieved using a distributed collective of small hydrophone-equipped subsurface floats, which utilize group management techniques and sensor fusion to understand the ocean soundscape in a Lagrangian manner. The ability to record soundscapes provides a novel sensing technology to understand the effects of sound on marine ecosystems and the role that sound plays for species development. Experiments off the coast of San Diego, CA, and a research campaign in the Cayman Islands provide concrete scientific studies that are tightly interwoven with the engineering research.

Oceans are drivers of global climate, are home to some of the most important and diverse ecosystems, and represent a substantial contribution to the world's economy as a major source of food and employment. The technological and scientific advances in this project provide crucial tools to understand natural ocean resources, by studying soundscapes at spatio-temporal scales that were heretofore extremely burdensome and expensive to obtain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oceans are drivers of global climate; they are home to some of our most important and diverse ecosystems; and they are play a big part in the world’s economy as a source of food and employment. Sound plays a vital role in the ocean ecosystem, as many organisms rely on the acoustic environment for navigation, communication, detecting predators and finding food. Therefore, the 3D underwater soundscape, i.e., the combination of sounds present in the immersive underwater environment, is of extreme importance to ultimately understanding and protecting underwater ecosystems. Of particular interest is the soundscape at the scales that would be experienced by the ocean organisms themselves, as well as the role that sound plays for species development (e.g., larval fish recruitment and settlement).

In this project, an underwater technology was created that records soundscapes using a swarm of small underwater vehicles. These vehicles are not actively propelled, but instead drift underwater on the ocean currents while they listen and record the sounds they hear. The challenge is that these vehicles need to know where they are in relation to each other, for the recordings to carry any useful information about the spatial distribution of the sounds. A set of techniques was created for exactly this purpose. The unique power of these techniques is that they do not rely on external infrastructure; i.e., no signals have to be injected into the environment. Instead, the soundscape itself is used to provide the necessary data that is then leveraged by sophisticated algorithms to derive positions of the swarm. These algorithms extract information from different types of sounds: isotropic sounds that are akin a background hum, motor noise of moving marine vehicles, and short burst noises one gets for example from colonies of snapping shrimp. The resulting algorithms provide inter-vehicle distance information for the swarm, which is combined to provide an overall view of the swarm geometry. Repeating this process over time enables tracking vehicle positions over time, thereby creating the spatio-temporal reference frame needed to interpret the sound recordings and linking it to the soundscape. A key intellectual contribution of this project is the development of these algorithms to extract information from various distinct types of soundscape scenarios. They have been optimized, analyzed and tested on data from actual ocean deployments of swarms of underwater drifters.

In addition to the swarm of vehicles, stationary listening stations were used to study the underwater soundscape in the Cayman Islands and the acoustic and spawning ecology of four sound producing fish: Nassau grouper, an endangered species, as well as red hind, black grouper, and yellowfin grouper. Analysis of the resulting data enabled an understanding of how these fish both contribute to and respond to their soundscape. This has significant applications to fisheries science and management. For example, this work resulted in the first continuous observations of movement of Nassau grouper and red hind over a week during the spawning season including preciously-unavailable nighttime observations.

In general, the technological and scientific advances of this project provide crucial tools to understand natural ocean resources, by studying soundscapes at scales that where heretofore extremely burdensome and expensive to obtain. It also provided opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to experience engineering in the context of real-world challenges with a real impact. The work in the Cayman Islands, part of the Grouper Moon project, in addition to also having a K-12 outreach component, contributed to the study and preservation of the Nassau grouper. Understanding how sound plays a role in spawning and larval settlement were key scientific questions that were targeted. This also provided a rich environment to field test the technologies, while providing concrete impacts as the same time.
